0 at 12:58, balakrishnan sengodan wrote:
>> With out using GET method, how =
do we test the method
>> that does not return value. Please give me an exam=
ple.

<snip />

>    publi=
c void testIncrementBy() {
>        Counter counter =3D new Counter();
>   =
     assertEquals("initial value", 0, counter.getCount());
>

   counter.incrementBy(5);
>        assertEquals("incremented value", 5, co=
unter.getCount());

<snip />

You could also try reading the question=
. :) :) :)  That looks suspiciously like using a get method.

To the OP, th=
ere are a number of ways to answer that question, depending on the actual d=
esign under test. If you can give us some information on what the 'void' me=
thod does, we may have a suggestion for you.

Consider the event/listener d=
esign in Java. An event source exposes 'addXXXListener' and 'removeXXXListe=
ner', but no methods to query the list of listeners. After all, only the ev=
ent source needs to know who the listeners are at any given moment.

You wa=
nt to test 'addXXXListener' to see whether it really does add the listener.=
 You have two choices.

1. Add 'containsXXXListener' to the event source an=
d use it in your tests. This is essentially the 'get' method you don't want=
 to use.

2. Add a listener to the event source, tell the event source to f=
ire an event, then check that the listener heard the event.

Option #1 is c=
leaner, although it adds a method 'just for testing'. Rather than drag up m=
y past comments in that direction, I suggest searching this group for the p=
hrase "just for testing" and read the messages you find.

Option #2 avoids =
the extra method, but relies on knowing how to fire an event, which kind of=
 event is fired and building a listener that listens for that kind of event=
 *and* can tell you whether it heard that event. That was a lot to type: th=
e code must be more work! Also if the event source changes its internal wor=
kings, your test may no longer work. With Option #1, there's not much dange=
r in the event source changing in a way that might break your test.

For de=
tails, look for "JUnit Cookbook" from Manning publications, although you'll=
 have to be patient -- it may not be on the shelf until early 2004.

Take c=
are.
